abstract.text: The description of a 3D object that you want ARKit to detect in the physical environment.

inlineContent.text: Object detection in ARKit lets you trigger AR content when the session recognizes a known 3D object. For example, your app could detect sculptures in an art museum and provide a virtual curator, or detect tabletop gaming figures and create visual effects for the game.
To provide a known 3D object for detection, you scan a real-world object using ARKit:
Run an AR session using
to enable collection of high-fidelity spatial mapping data.

In that session, point the device camera at the real-world object from various angles, allowing ARKit to build up an internal map of the object and its surroundings. For an example of guiding user interactions to produce good scan data, see
Determine the portion of the session’s world coordinate space representing the object to be recognized, and call
to get that portion as an
ready for use in object detection.
To save the reference object for use later or elsewhere, use the
method to create an
file.
To detect objects in an AR session, pass a collection of reference objects to your session configuration’s
property. You need not scan and detect objects in the same app: For example, you might create one app for scanning museum collections that outputs
files, then bundle those files into another app meant for museum visitors.
To bundle reference objects into an app, use your Xcode project’s asset catalog:
In your asset catalog, use the Add (+) button to create an AR Resource Group.
Drag
into the resource group to create AR Reference Object entries in the asset catalog.
Optionally, use the Xcode inspector panel to provide a descriptive name for the object, which appears as the
property at runtime and can be useful for debugging.

abstract.text: Integrate hardware sensing features to produce augmented reality apps and games.
An anchor for a real-world 3D object that ARKit detects in the physical environment.
A configuration that recognizes objects and collects high-fidelity data about specific objects using the rear-facing camera.
The description of a 3D object that you want ARKit to detect in the physical environment.
Returns a new reference object created by applying the specified transform to this reference object’s geometric data.
The standard filename extension for exported
instances.
The center point of the reference object’s space-mapping data.
Writes a binary representation of the object to the specified file URL.
The size of the reference object’s space-mapping data.
Loads a reference object from the specified file URL.
Returns a new reference object that combines spatial information from both this reference object and another.
A descriptive name for the reference object.
A coarse representation of the space-mapping data contained in the reference object.
Loads all reference objects in the specified AR Resource Group in your Xcode project’s asset catalog.
A scale factor for the local coordinate space the reference object defines.
Creates a reference object (for 3D object detection) from the specified region of the session’s world space.
A set of 3D objects that the framework attempts to detect in the user’s environment.
Record spatial features of real-world objects, then use the results to find those objects in the user’s environment and trigger AR content.
Estimate the shape of the physical environment using a polygonal mesh.

doc://com.apple.arkit/documentation/ARKi.title: Visualizing and interacting with a reconstructed scene

abstract.text: The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables encoding and decoding in a manner that is robust against object substitution attacks.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
